siteMetadata.title: Complete Intro to Linux and the CLI
siteMetadata.subtitle: Learn how to use the command
siteMetadata.description: The complete intro to using Linux and the command line as taught by Brian Holt

frontmatter.title: Introduction
frontmatter.description: this is the description that will show up in social shares

frontmatter.title: What you will learn
frontmatter.description: It is always good to go in knowing what you're about to learn. Brian goes over why this course is useful to you and what problems Linux is going to solve for you.

frontmatter.title: What is Linux
frontmatter.description: What is Linux? Why do you need it? Brian goes into why we need Linux and where it came from

frontmatter.title: Let's Run Linux
frontmatter.description: Brian goes over how to get Linux running on Windows 10 and macOS computers with either VirtualBox or Multipass

frontmatter.title: Anatomy of a CLI Command
frontmatter.description: Brian talk about what the command line is, why you'd want to use it, and how to get started with it

frontmatter.title: Common Tips and Tricks
frontmatter.description: Brian talks about the common tips and tricks of the command line like what tilda means, how to find commands you previously ran, and other things to make your life on the command line

frontmatter.title: Signals and the the Power of CTRL
frontmatter.description: Brian talks about how and when to use CTRL when working with the command line: to send signals to bash and to accomplish shortcuts

frontmatter.title: nano
frontmatter.description: Brian discusses one of the most common and most available text editors for the command line, nano

frontmatter.title: vim
frontmatter.description: Brian answers the age old question: how do you exit vim? In this section Brian goes over the very basics of vim so it will never intimidate you again.

frontmatter.title: Interacting with Files
frontmatter.description: How do you interact with files in the command line? Brian goes over the essential programs for inteacting with files in Linux.

frontmatter.title: Wildcards and Replacements
frontmatter.description: Using a few tricks you can cleverly select multiple files at a time with bash. Brian in this section will go over wilcards, expansions, and replacements

frontmatter.title: Streams and Pipes
frontmatter.description: Linux has an interesting concept called streams. The most common of these are stdout, stderr, and stdin. Brian goes over what streams are and how to pipe them together.

frontmatter.title: Users, Groups, and Permissions
frontmatter.description: Another core function of Linux is its security and permission model. This centers around the concepts of users, groups, and permissions. Brian explains what this means to a user of Linux.
